text: I'm Catherine.
And I'm Neil.

text: Don't be silly, Neil. I think I'd know if you were in my family.

text: Well, we'll talk more about that later in the show,
but I should say at this point that today we're discussing genealogy.
Well, the study of family history, and I think it's pretty fascinating stuff.
Do you ever watch the TV programme, who do you think you are, Catherine?
You know, where celebrities find out about their family history?
Yeah, I've seen a couple of them.
For example, one celebrity who was very proud of his working class,
London Roots, or Origins,
discovered that he's actually a direct descendant of an English king.
Well, that's quite a discovery.
The thing is, though, Catherine,
what if there isn't anything exciting in your family history?
skeletons in the closet
speaker: Neil

text: Well, I reckon if you go back far enough, Neil,
there's always something exciting or unexpected in anybody's family history.
And skeletons in the closet, by the way, means secrets.
Now, I think it's time for today's quiz question.
Researching family history often involves reading old documents
such as birth, marriage and death certificates,
and these can be difficult to decipher or understand.
So, what's the name for the study of ancient handwriting?
Is it A, scriptography, B, paleography, or C, scribeology?
Well, it must be a) Scriptography.
speaker: Neil

text: And we'll see if you're right or not later on in the show.
Now, why do you think most people look into their genealogy, Neil?
Is it just curiosity?
Well, Catherine, we all love a good mystery story,
especially if it's connected with our own family.
And these days, it's easy to do research online,
because many old paper documents have been digitised
and are available online.
BBC presenter Mike Williams investigated his own family history.
And here he's talking about his great grandfather's story.
And if you listen very carefully, you can hear him rustling the real paper documents.
The Williams is on my father's side and on my mother's,
the hynno's, it's a name that we think comes from Finland.
And if I look at this document here,
it's a copy of the Census of England Wales 1911.
You can see my grandfather, Miss Sun,
and his father, the head of the household,
Michael Heiner, or Mikael Heiner,
who the family law has it, jumped ship and ended up in Liverpool.
What's a census, Catherine?
speaker: census

text: It's an official count of people in a population.
So, Mike Williams' great grandfather appeared on the 1911 census for England and Wales,
but because of his surname, the family think he might originally have come from Finland.
The exciting event in Mike Williams' history,
passed down through family law, which means knowledge passed on from one generation to the next,
is that his great-grandfather jumped ship.
Which means he left the ship he was working on without permission to do so.
speaker: Catherine

text: And he started a new life in England.
And he started a new life in England. I suppose quite a few people have immigration stories in their family histories – sometimes without knowing it.

text: sometimes without knowing it.
Actually, that's something that many people are fascinated by.
And has also become easier to investigate these days,
now companies offer to test the DNA in your saliva for as little as $100.
And then they come up with results saying you're related to Alexander the Great or Brad Pitt.
Remember, I said that we were related.
Well, let's now listen to El's Churchill from the Society of Genealogists here in London
who explains what I meant.
There is what you might call the gateway ancestor,
in the idea of history and genealogies.
That's normally somebody that's so well documented that their descendants are well known.
In England, it's something I can, over the third.
And we're all probably descended from Edward III.
Isn't it nice to have royal ancestors?
Well, millions of people are descended from Edward III.
And so in that sense, that's where the connection might be.
So the chances are, a lot of people are distantly connected to each other.
El's Churchill says it's likely that millions of us are
distantly related to a gateway ancestor,
like King Edward III of England.
And that means that all those people related to Edward III
are also distantly related to each other.
So it seems that paying a company $100 to reveal that you're related to Edward III
is a waste of money.
Yes, in the sense that it's you and millions of other people.
Yes, in the sense that it's you and millions of other people. And in fact, we're all related to each other somehow, via Edward III or someone else.

text: And another popular finding for British people
is to say that you're descended from the Vikings.
And again, this is true from lots of people,
so it isn't particularly meaningful.
If you're descended from a person or a group it means they are among your ancestors.

text: it means they are among your ancestors.
Now, remember I asked: what's the name for the study of ancient handwriting? Is it…
speaker: Catherine

text: Is it A, scriptography, B, paleography, or C, scribology?
I said a) Scriptography. And I'm pretty confident that's the right answer.
speaker: Neil

text: Well, near your pretty confident, but unfortunately, it was wrong.
The correct answer is B, paleography.
P paleography is the study of ancient and historical handwriting,
including the practice of deciphering, reading, and dating historical manuscripts.
Oh well, here are the words we learned:
